bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, June 8, 1943

div1.p: Kellogg assures Hench that he will still be involved with the "Pioneers of American Medicine Series," despite the fact that he no longer with Wyeth. He and Cornwell received an award from the National Art Director's Club. He expresses concern about Kean.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, June 8, 1943
div1.opener:
Kellogg
Johnson & Johnson
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J.
June 8, 43
Dear Phil,
div1.p:
Thanks for your kind note.
You may be sure I'll not drop my
association with the Pioneers of American
Medicine Series - Cornwell is doing two
this year. “Procter, Father of American
Pharmacy” and “Oliver Wendell Holmes”

Cornwell and I received the Award
of Distinguished Merit from the Nat'l
Art Directors Club - at a dinner in N.Y.C.
last night for “The Dawn of Abdominal
Surgery” If we had submitted “Conquerors
of Yellow Fever” the year it came out
I think we would have gotten the Gold
Medal.

I'm going to see my brother at Carlisle
Barracks tonight. It looks like a real
move to action may come for him soon.
Johnson & Johnson
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J.
At least, he hopes so.

I hope your family are all
well and that you see them frequently.

This new job is an interesting
one with unusual possibilities. A. H. P.
reorganized their whole advertising set
up and I didn't like the prospects too
well -- when, to my great pleasure
J & J sought me out as the leading
pharmaceutical Adv. man in the country
in which I was willing to concur at
a price.

I needed a change, I think
and this is a real one although I
continue to live in N. Y. C.

I'm worried about Gen'l Kean.
I've had no word from him since the
day of the dedication of the Jefferson Memorial.
